title: Depletion and reconstitution of macrophages in mice with vesicular stomatitis virus infection
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
      Induction and isolation of CD45.2+ murine peritoneal
      macrophages
    
Timing: 72 h
      This section describes the main steps to induce and collect peritoneal
      macrophages in donor mice. Upon 6% starch solution injection, macrophages
      are recruited to the peritoneal cavity and phagocytosed starch granules.
      After starch induction, 1–2×107 macrophages can be recruited.
      The proportion of macrophages in the collected peritoneal lavage fluid
      reaches 80–90%. To clearly distinguish donor and recipient cells,
      CD45.1+ and CD45.2+ mice are used. By this way, the
      efficiency of adoptive transfer can be detected by flow cytometry. We used
      CD45.2+ mice as donor mice and CD45.1+ as recipient
      mice here. The genotypes of recipient and donor mice can be determined by
      the experimental design.
    
        Intraperitoneally inject CD45.2+ C57BL/6J mice with 0.7–1 mL
        sterile 6% starch solution.
      
3 days later, sacrifice the mice by anesthesia.
Critical: The number of infiltrating
      macrophages peaks at 3 days.
    
        Soak the mice in 75% alcohol for 3 min and then move them to the
        ultra-clean workbench.
      
        Cut the skin of mice to expose the peritoneum. Use scissors to carefully
        make a small incision in the center of the peritoneum.
      
        Irrigate the peritoneum with 1 mL sterile PBS by sterile dropper. Repeat
        for 4–5 times until the irrigating solution becomes clear.
      
Critical: Irrigate gently to avoid
      intraperitoneal bleeding.
    
Note: The final volume of irrigating
      solution is about 4 mL. To avoid liquid lost, we recommend gently
      collecting the lavage against the lateral wall of the peritoneal cavity.
    
        Centrifuge the irrigating solution at 500 × g for 5 min.
        Remove the supernatants.
      
Note: If a large number of red blood cells
      (RBC) exist in the peritoneal lavage fluid, resuspend cell pellets with
      3 mL mouse RBC lysis buffer. Place on ice for 5 min. Centrifuge at

500 × g for 5 min and then discard the supernatants. Resuspend the
      pellets with 5 mL PBS. Centrifuge at 500 × g for 5 min and discard
      the supernatants.
    
        Suspend the cell pellets using DMEM medium supplemented with 10% FBS and
        1% penicillin–streptomycin. Adjust the cell density to 2
        × 106/mL.
      
        Seed the cells on the 10 cm cell culture dishes. Place the dishes at
        37°C under 5% CO2 for 4 h.
      
        Discard the supernatants to remove the unattached cells. Wash the dishes
        with PBS.
      
        Add fresh DMEM medium supplemented with 10% FBS and 1%
        penicillin–streptomycin. Culture the cells at 37°C with 5% CO2
        for 24 h.
      
Note: Approximately 1 × 107
      peritoneal macrophages can be collected from a C57BL/6J mouse 3 days after
      1 mL-starch injection.
    
Pause point: The donor peritoneal
      macrophages can be cultured at 37°C with 5% CO2 for 48 h before
      proceeding to the next step.
    
      Macrophage depletion in CD45.1+ recipient mice
    
Timing: 48 h
      This section describes the main procedure to clear macrophages in
      CD45.1+ recipient mice. Clodronate liposomes are phagocytosed
      by macrophages and induced apoptosis by blocking mitochondrial respiratory
      chain, which finally results in the depletion of macrophages. After the
      depletion of CD45.1+ macrophages, the recipient mice can
      receive CD45.2+ macrophages, which can be derived from a
      specific gene knock mouse. Therefore, the function of the donor
      macrophages can be clearly characterized.
    
        Intraperitoneally inject CD45.1+ C57BL/6J mice with 200 μL
        sterile clodronate liposome.
      
        The mice are maintained in a normal chow diet under specific
        pathogen-free conditions for 2 days.

Note: The clearance efficiency of

macrophages can be analyzed by flow cytometry (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
    
      Adoptive transfer of CD45.2+ macrophages into CD45.1+
      recipient mice
    
Timing: 1 h
      This section describes the steps of CD45.2+ donor macrophages
      transferred into CD45.1+ recipient mice.
    
        Scrape CD45.2+ donor peritoneal macrophages from culture dish
        by a cell scraper.
      
Cell counting. Adjust cell density to 2×107/mL.
        Gently vortex the cell suspension. Fill a 1 mL syringe with 100 μL cell
        suspension.
      
Critical: The volume of the transfer
      liquid should not exceed 200 μL.
    
Note: To ensure that the cell suspension
      is homogeneous before injection, step 15 should be done immediately before
      injection of each mouse.
    
        Place a heater around the mice for 10 min to dilate the tail veins.
      
        Find the tail veins of CD45.1+ recipient mice. Clean it with
        alcohol swabs.
      
        Insert the needle at an angle parallel to the tail veins. Inject 100 μL
        cell suspension (2×106 cells).
      
        Remove the needle. Apply pressure to the injection site with gauze until
        there is no more bleeding.

Note: The transfer efficiency can be
      determined by CD45.1+/CD45.2+ proportion of
      macrophages in recipient mice 24 h after adoptive transfer (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
    
In vivo VSV infection
Timing: 24 h
      This section describes the steps to infect CD45.1+ recipient
      mice with VSV in vivo.
    
Rapid thawing VSV.
        Intraperitoneal inject VSV into CD45.1+ recipient mice
        (5 × 107 PFU per mouse).
      
24 h later, the mice are sacrificed after anesthesia.
